I really enjoy your videos, including this one.  However, you have triggered one of my pet peeves.  You use "dampen" (to make moist) when you really should be using "damp" (to check or diminish the activity or vigor of).  The difference is implied in the video title - it's a tuned mass damper, not a tuned mass dampener.

SInce no one answered (I think!) the question I took upon myself to do the testing: I found that a a 37 gram weight with a 38mm long thread was the most useful balance.  I used a larger nut for mine.  Anything from 30-40 grams seems to work fine, after that I found the rig became less stable.

Loved it! You can also use CFD, as you briefly shown, to assess design issues such as vortex shedding, galloping and flutter, and make necessary modifications to counter these. The Taipei 101 is a good example, where the original, and simpler, corners were redesigned when a CFD study shown they shed vortices at frequencies close to the natural of the building.

I've got a question:

We know that the universe is 13.8 billion years old. However, Einstein's theories of special relativity has taught us that time moves at different rates for different observers... I.e. the age of the universe is 13.8 billion years old for us, but would vary for different observers in the universe. In other words, since time itself is relative to different observers, the age of the universe is relative for different observers too.

How much would this measurement vary from our solar system to the next? How much would it vary from our galaxy to the next? From our galaxy cluster to the next? More generally, is there some function which can take in the required variables and spit out the age of the universe for that observer?

Any insight would be appreciated :)

Suppose you put Schrodinger in a box with a gun strapped to his head. He tells you that he will measure himself at the end of 1 hour, after which there is a 50% chance of the gun firing. At the end of one hour, he collapses into one state (alive or dead) if he measures himself. Then at the end of one hour, he is alive and collapsed, OR dead and uncollapsed.  Its superposition-ception!

Another neet thing I've see using spring weights is earthquake resistance under the foundation. You put the entire building on an unfixed foundation so the building can slide back and forth, but the foundation also have a grid pattern of blocks and springs so that the friction of the earth moving under the foundation is lost into this network and the building actually stand rather still.

That's all great but for Earthquakes it's not nearly enough. Japan has buildings with compressed air under the supports that sit on large flat discs. When they sense an Earthquake they can effectively hover the entire building like an air hockey puck for 30 seconds to a minute or something like that. There was an NHK documentary here in Japan all about how most of the buildings in Japan are not designed to handle the type of Earthquake that hit Kumamoto in 2016. Where as most earthquakes shake back and forth the Kumamoto Earthquake started with an instant shove . That shove is too fast for tuned mass dampers to help prevent issue apparently.

Damping vs. Dampening: An engineering professor whose course I was taking stressed that the correct term in regards to dampers reducing vibration/oscilation is "damping" and "damps". In his words, "dampening" was when you added moisture. In the years since, I rarely see damping/damps used, almost everyone uses dampening. Every time I hear it I wonder if he was correct.

Love your videos so much! just wanted to point out at 1:28 and 1:55, that while "to dampen" and "this dampens" are not necessarily incorrect (definition: "make less strong or intense"), it is more appropriate in these situations to phrase it as "to damp" or "this damps" (definition: "PHYSICS: progressively reduce the amplitude of (an oscillation or vibration)"), especially since the title and content specifically mention dampers in this context. Again, your content is marvelous and this point is small. Definitions sourced from Google search dictionary and corroborated with Dictionary.com

Fun fact: F1 outlawed the tuned mass damper because they considered it a movable aerodynamic device.  Even though it was completely by bodywork and not exposed to the air stream.  And even though if you make the rotary equivalent with a torsion spring and flywheel its just fine according to the rules.
